etymologies: Old English, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zelf and German selbe. Early use was emphatic, expressing the sense ‘(I) myself’, ‘(he) himself’, etc. The verb dates from the early 20th century

definitions: a person's essential being that distinguishes them from others, especially considered as the object of introspection or reflexive action

examples.text: our alienation from our true selves
guilt can be turned against the self
language is an aspect of a person's sense of self

shortDefinitions: person's essential being that distinguishes them from others

definitions: a person's particular nature or personality; the qualities that make a person individual or unique

examples.text: by the end of the round he was back to his old self
Paula seemed to be her usual cheerful self
to love in an unpossessive way implies the total surrender of self

definitions: used ironically to refer to oneself or someone else

examples.text: the only side worth supporting is your own sweet self

shortDefinitions: used ironically to refer to oneself or someone else

definitions: (of a trimming or cover) of the same material and color as the rest of the item
shortDefinitions: (of trimming or cover) of same material and colour as rest of item

examples.text: a variety that selfs itself loses lots of vigor in the progeny

definitions: cause (an animal or plant) to breed with or fertilize one of the same hybrid origin or strain

examples.text: in each progeny, three to five plants were selfed

shortDefinitions: cause animal or plant to breed with or fertilize one of same hybrid origin or strain
